{{Infobox organization | image = The_Mars_Generation_Logo.jpg | formation = {{start date and age|2015|01|01}} | type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] Nonprofit corporation 501(c)(3) | status = The Mars Generation is a "public charity" and is eligible to receive tax-deductible charitable contributions | purpose = STEM education and space advocacy for human mission to Mars | headquarters = Minneapolis, Minnesota, United States | key_people = Board of Directors: * [[Abigail Harrison]] (Chair) * Gordon Russell (Treasurer), [[Orbital ATK]] * Yvonne Hundshamer (Secretary) * Nicole Harrison (Executive Director)
Advisory Board: *[[Astronaut]] [[Dorothy Metcalf-Lindenburger]] * [[Astronaut]] [[Wendy Lawrence]] *[[Astronaut]] [[Kent Rominger]], Vice President [[Orbital ATK]] * Elizabeth Bierman [[Honeywell]] & [[Society of Women Engineers]] * Myron Fletcher, [[Boeing]] * Dr. Phil Metzger, [[University of Central Florida]] & Co-Founder [[NASA]] [[Swamp Works]] Lab * [[Robert Pearlman]], [[collectSPACE]] * Dawn Brown White, [[Nonprofit]] CEO * Sean Costello, CEO * Kathleen Butts, Urban Educator * Kristin Maija Peterson, Art Director * Michael Seely, Nonprofit President * Kate-Madonna Hindes, PR Professional
Student Space Ambassador Program Advisory Board: * Ken Buckley (Chair) * Morgan Irons (Vice Chair) * Nicole Chase (Director of SSA) | slogan = Dream Big! Act Big! Inspire Others! | founder = Abigail Harrison "Astronaut Abby" | website = {{URL|themarsgeneration.org}} | abbreviation = TMG }}
'''The Mars Generation''' is an American internationally active, [[Non-governmental organization|non-governmental]] [[nonprofit organization]] involved in public outreach and advocating for [[Human spaceflight|human space exploration]] and [[science, technology, engineering, and mathematics]] (STEM) education.
The mission of The Mars Generation is to educate and inspire people of all ages about [[science]], [[technology]], [[engineering]], and [[mathematics]] (STEM) and human space exploration and the importance of space and STEM to the future of humankind.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://college.usatoday.com/2017/03/17/meet-abby-harrison-the-college-sophomore-headed-for-mars/|title=Meet Abby Harrison, the college sophomore headed for Mars|date=2017-03-17|website=USA TODAY College|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.guidestar.org/profile/46-2505480|title=The Mars Generation – GuideStar Profile|website=www.guidestar.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref> The Mars Generation is volunteer-driven by executive and advisory boards with leaders from the space industry including astronauts, engineers and scientists as well as nonprofit, education and business sectors.since its founding in 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/30544-astronaut-abby-launches-mars-generation.html|title=Launching 'The Mars Generation': Teen on Mission to Get People to Mars|work=Space.com|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kare11.com/life/family/kids-who-kare/kare-about-kids-astronaut-abby/23105189|title=Kids who KARE: Astronaut Abby|last=TEGNA|work=KARE|access-date=2017-08-13|language=en-US}}</ref>
In June 2017, The Mars Generation<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.themarsgeneration.org/|title=The Mars Generation|website=The Mars Generation|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref> was recognized with a business innovation award for their use of technology to build the organization and its programs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/news/2017/06/20/2017-eureka-innovation-award-winner-the-mars.html|title=2017 Eureka! Innovation award winner: The Mars Generation|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref> This unique approach to creating a nonprofit is credited to the organization's founder and leader [[Abigail Harrison]] leveraging her own [[Internet celebrity|internet personality]] as Astronaut Abby to grow the organization. As of August 2017, The Mars Generation and Astronaut Abby have over one million followers of their combined social media channels and have reached an estimated 25 million.
==History==
The Mars Generation was founded in 2015 by 18-year-old [[Abigail Harrison]], popularly known as "Astronaut Abby" and has the support of high-level advisory board members which includes astronauts, engineers and scientists as well as [[Nonprofit organization|nonprofit]], [[education]] and [[business]] professionals.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/30544-astronaut-abby-launches-mars-generation.html|title=Launching 'The Mars Generation': Teen on Mission to Get People to Mars|work=Space.com|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://college.usatoday.com/2017/03/17/meet-abby-harrison-the-college-sophomore-headed-for-mars/|title=Meet Abby Harrison, the college sophomore headed for Mars|date=2017-03-17|website=USA TODAY College|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref>
Harrison started [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] and space advocacy work at the age of 13 by initially setting up a [[Twitter]] account under her childhood nickname "Astronaut Abby." She used her @AstronautAbby<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/AstronautAbby|title=Abigail Harrison (@AstronautAbby) {{!}} Twitter|website=twitter.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref> Twitter account to connect with [[NASA]] employees to try and procure a quote for her National History Day project.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/audience/forstudents/5-8/features/astronaut-abby-hearts-nasa.html|title=NASA – Astronaut Abby Hearts NASA|website=www.nasa.gov|language=en|others=Flint Wild : MSFC, Shelley Canright : HQ, Diedra Williams : MSFC, Cindy McArthur : JSC, Rachel Kraft : JSC, Ann Marie Trotta : HQ, Nicole Harrison : POC, Abby Harrison : POC|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref> Her account biography stated that she was aspiring to be an astronaut and had a goal to be the first person to set foot on Mars. After she received the NASA quote, she began to share her journey to Mars which included tweets about space events, school and her personal life with the goal of not only exciting people about mars exploration but creating advocates for human space exploration.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/audience/forstudents/5-8/features/astronaut-abby-hearts-nasa.html|title=NASA – Astronaut Abby Hearts NASA|website=www.nasa.gov|language=en|others=Flint Wild : MSFC, Shelley Canright : HQ, Diedra Williams : MSFC, Cindy McArthur : JSC, Rachel Kraft : JSC, Ann Marie Trotta : HQ, Nicole Harrison : POC, Abby Harrison : POC|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref>
In May 2013, at 15-years old, Harrison partnered with her mentor, Astronaut [[Luca Parmitano]] as his [[Earth]] Liaison and shared his experience living in space on the [[International Space Station]] during [[Expedition 36]] and [[Expedition 37]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.universetoday.com/101824/why-an-astronaut-asked-15-year-old-abby-to-help-get-the-word-out/#more-101824|title=Why An Astronaut Asked 15 Year Old Abby to Help Get The Word Out – Universe Today|date=2013-04-30|work=Universe Today|access-date=2017-08-13|language=en-US}}</ref> Harrison setup an international outreach program consisting of classroom web chats, an [[email]] [[pen pal]] program, [[classroom]] visits, blogging on AstronautAbby.com, writing for other publications, speaking at events, and sharing on [[social media]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://explorecuriocity.org/Explore/ArticleId/2326/astronaut-abby-2326.aspx|title=CurioCity – CurioCité {{!}} Astronaut Abby|website=explorecuriocity.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref> Initially called the Soyuz Adventure, after Astronaut Parmitano returned to [[Earth]], it was renamed "The Future of Space" and Harrison continued to run the program.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/astronaut-abby-is-crowdfunding-her-way-to-outer-space/208184441/|title='Astronaut Abby' is crowdfunding her way to outer space|work=Star Tribune|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://skepticlab.com/episode/029-mission-to-mars-with-astronaut-abby/|title=#029 – Mission to Mars with Astronaut Abby – SkepticLab|work=SkepticLab|access-date=2017-08-13|language=en-US}}</ref> This program was the basis for the development of The Mars Generation nonprofit in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://college.usatoday.com/2017/03/17/meet-abby-harrison-the-college-sophomore-headed-for-mars/|title=Meet Abby Harrison, the college sophomore headed for Mars|date=2017-03-17|website=USA TODAY College|access-date=2017-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://sea.pcmag.com/news/9272/mars-and-the-public-imagination|title=Mars and the Public Imagination|date=2016-01-05|work=PCMag Asia|access-date=2017-08-13|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Programs==
===Core programs===
The Mars Generation offers 3 core programs that are focused on helping the organization reach its mission of exciting and educating people of all ages about STEM education and human space exploration.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.space.com/30544-astronaut-abby-launches-mars-generation.html|title=Launching 'The Mars Generation': Teen on Mission to Get People to Mars|work=Space.com|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/news/2017/06/20/2017-eureka-innovation-award-winner-the-mars.html|title=https://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/news/2017/06/20/2017-eureka-innovation-award-winner-the-mars.html|website=www.bizjournals.com|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
====The Future of Space Outreach Program====
The Future of Space Outreach program excites and educates people of all ages about human space exploration as well as [[science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] education and encourages the support of space exploration and STEM education.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/launching-mars-generation-teen-mission-people-mars-144638601.html|title=Launching 'The Mars Generation': Teen on Mission to Get People to Mars|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/news/2017/06/20/2017-eureka-innovation-award-winner-the-mars.html|title=2017 Eureka! Innovation award winner: The Mars Generation|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2497161,00.asp|title=Mars and the Public Imagination|work=PCMAG|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en}}</ref>
====Student Space Ambassador Leadership Program====
The Student Space Ambassador Leadership Program (SSA) is a dual program in mentorship and leadership designed to provide school and career guidance to students ages 13–24.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.space.com/30544-astronaut-abby-launches-mars-generation.html|title=Launching 'The Mars Generation': Teen on Mission to Get People to Mars|work=Space.com|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref> The program also provides encouragement for students to share their passion and excitement about space exploration and STEM education as ambassadors within their communities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://college.usatoday.com/2017/03/17/meet-abby-harrison-the-college-sophomore-headed-for-mars/|title=Meet Abby Harrison, the college sophomore headed for Mars|date=2017-03-17|website=USA TODAY College|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2497161,00.asp|title=Mars and the Public Imagination|work=PCMAG|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en}}</ref>
====Space Camp Scholarship Program====
This program provides full paid scholarships to include transportation, flight suits and a small spending stipend for students demonstrating financial need to attend U.S. Space Camp.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://college.usatoday.com/2017/03/17/meet-abby-harrison-the-college-sophomore-headed-for-mars/|title=Meet Abby Harrison, the college sophomore headed for Mars|date=2017-03-17|website=USA TODAY College|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2497161,00.aspv|title=Mars and the Public Imagination|work=PCMAG|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en}}</ref> In order to apply for consideration students need to be age 15–17, demonstrate interest in space exploration and an aptitude in STEM and complete the application, including obtaining a recommendation from a teacher and/or mentor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.guidestar.org/profile/46-2505480|title=The Mars Generation – GuideStar Profile|website=www.guidestar.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kare11.com/mobile/article/life/family/kids-who-kare/kids-who-kare-astronaut-abby/89-23105189|title=Kids who KARE: Astronaut Abby|work=KARE|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Additional programs and initiatives===
====24 Under 24 Leaders and Innovators In STEAM and Space Awards==== In March 2017, The Mars Generation announced the launch of the 24 Under 24 Leaders and Innovators In STEAM and Space Awards, a program designed to recognize and encourage students and young adults who are making a significant impact in the world through space and/or STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.blogtalkradio.com/somewhereinvegas/2017/04/24/live-in-la-with-mars-generation-abigail-harrison-musician-clare-means|title=Live in L.A. with "Mars Generation" Abigail Harrison & Musician Clare Means|website=BlogTalkRadio|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.moroccanews.com/the-mars-generation-launches-24-under-24-leaders-and-innovators-in-steam-and-space-annual-awards-program/|title=The Mars Generation Launches 24 Under 24: Leaders and Innovators in STEAM and Space Annual Awards Program {{!}} Moroccan News Update|work=Moroccan News Update|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.the-kenyan.co.ke/the-mars-generation-launches-24-under-24-leaders-and-innovators-in-steam-and-space-annual-awards-program|title=The Mars Generation Launches 24 Under 24: Leaders and Innovators in STEAM and Space Annual Awards Program|last=https://www.the-kenyan.co.ke/|date=2017-04-20|work=Kenya's Content Aggregator,The Breaking News Headliner in Politics,Sports,Business,Videos And More.|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
====Train Like A Martian Challenge====
The Train Like A Martian Challenge is an annual event sponsored by The Mars Generation that raises awareness about human space exploration and [[science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] education while encouraging people of all ages to become more physically active. The event challenges participants to participate in a daily activity and share videos and photos of the activity on social media channels using the #TrainLikeAMartian hashtag.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.space.com/32087-train-like-a-martian-kids-challenge.html|title='Train Like a Martian' Challenge Inspires Kids to Get Active|work=Space.com|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
====Membership program====
In 2016, The Mars Generation launched its membership program providing a way for people to support the organization while receiving perks that are only available to members. These membership perks include invitations to special events, discounts, updates and offers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.universetoday.com/132738/weekly-space-hangout-january-6-2017-abigail-astronaut-abby-harrison/|title=Weekly Space Hangout – January 6, 2017: Abigail "Astronaut Abby" Harrison – Universe Today|date=2017-01-06|work=Universe Today|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.astronautabby.com/join-celebrate-one-year-orbit/|title=Join Astronaut Abby To Celebrate One Year in Orbit {{!}} Astronaut Abby|date=2016-09-15|work=Astronaut Abby|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Partnerships and engagements==
===Partnerships===
The Mars Generation has several strategic partnerships with organizations to help promote advocacy and excitement for STEM and space exploration.
====[[Team America Rocketry Challenge]]====
An outreach partnership was formed in 2016 between The Mars Generation and the [[Team America Rocketry Challenge]] (TARC), a nationwide American [[model rocketry]] competition that is sponsored by the [[Aerospace Industries Association]] and the [[National Association of Rocketry]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://rocketcontest.org/sponsors/|title=Team America Rocketry Challenge {{!}}|work=TARC|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://rocketcontest.org/news/for-the-media/|title=Team America Rocketry Challenge {{!}}|work=TARC|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aia-aerospace.org/tarc-students-showcase-rockets-as-president-obama-highlights-mars-generation-at-science-fair/|title=TARC Students Showcase Rockets as President Obama Highlights "Mars Generation" at Science Fair – Aerospace Industries Association|website=www.aia-aerospace.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
====Explore Mars====
In 2016 an outreach partnership was formed with Explore Mars the organization that hosts the annual Humans to Mars Summit, a leading Mars advocacy and information conference.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://h2m.exploremars.org/#sponsors|title=The Humans to Mars Summit|website=h2m.exploremars.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://spaceref.com/news/viewpr.html?pid=50825|title=Humans Will Walk on Mars by the Early 2030s|website=spaceref.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://spacenews.com/event/2016-humans-to-mars-summit/|title=2016 Humans to Mars Summit – SpaceNews.com|work=SpaceNews.com|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
====[[National Geographic Kids]]====
An outreach partnership was formed in 2017 between The Mars Generation and [[National Geographic Kids]] to promote STEAM awareness through their [[Guinness World Records]] rocket project.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://kids.nationalgeographic.com/explore/contests/guinness-world-records/partners/|title=Partners|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://press.nationalgeographic.com/2017/07/10/national-geographic-kids-and-toyota-set-new-record-for-worlds-largest-toilet-paper-roll-sculpture/|title=National Geographic Kids and Toyota Set New Record for World's "Largest Toilet-Paper-Roll Sculpture" – National Geographic Partners Press Room|last=Room|first=National Geographic Press|last2=Room|first2=National Geographic Press|date=2017-07-10|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://kids.nationalgeographic.com/explore/contests/guinness-world-records/get-involved/#rocket-assembly4.jpg|title=Get Involved|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
===Engagements===
As an international outreach organization, The Mars Generation has been invited to attend multiple engagements to talk about the nonprofit and outreach work they do to excite and educate people about space exploration and [[science, technology, engineering, and mathematics]] (STEM) education.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/launching-mars-generation-teen-mission-people-mars-144638601.html|title=Launching 'The Mars Generation': Teen on Mission to Get People to Mars|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref>
====TEDx Snowlibaries====
(2015) – The Mars Generation Advisory board member, [[Astronaut]] [[Dorothy Metcalf-Lindenburger]] gave a TEDx talk titled "The Mars Generation" where she shared her own journey to becoming an astronaut, the past and present of human spaceflight|human space exploration and how The Mars Generation nonprofit is playing a role in the future of human spaceflight|human space exploration.<ref>{{Citation|last=TEDx Talks|title=The Mars Generation {{!}} Dorothy (Dottie) Metcalf-Lindenburger {{!}} TEDxSnoIsleLibraries|date=2016-01-12|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GKjScLeyNJk|accessdate=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tedxinnovations.ted.com/2016/07/07/10-tedx-talks-by-women-whove-been-to-space/|title=10 TEDx Talks by women who've been to space|date=2016-07-07|website=TEDx Innovations Blog|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
====Humans to Mars Summit====
(2016 & 2017) – The Mars Generation founder [[Abigail Harrison]] represented The Mars Generation as a speaker for the 2016 and 2017 Humans to Mars Summit hosted by Explore Mars in [[Washington D.C.]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://h2m.exploremars.org|title=The Humans to Mars Summit|website=h2m.exploremars.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.exploremars.org|title=Explore Mars – Humans to Mars by the 2030s|website=www.exploremars.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://spacenews.com/event/2016-humans-to-mars-summit/|title=2016 Humans to Mars Summit – SpaceNews.com|work=SpaceNews.com|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://spaceref.com/news/viewpr.html?pid=50825|title=Humans Will Walk on Mars by the Early 2030s|website=spaceref.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
====Project Space Forum====
(2017) – The [[Mohammed bin Rashid Space Centre]] located in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]] invited The Mars Generation founder [[Abigail Harrison]] to tour their space agency and speak at their Project Space forum as an representative of The Mars Generation and an international space ambassador<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://code.likeagirl.io/on-her-way-to-mars-4c87705b1031|title=On Her way to Mars – Code Like A Girl|date=2017-01-17|work=Code Like A Girl|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wellesley.edu/news/2017/node/110191#CwkRwgmaCoOTZG1Z.97|title=Astronaut Abby's Journey to Mars|website=Wellesley College|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.emirates247.com/news/emirates/mbrsc-launches-the-project-space-forum-on-january-24-2017-01-18-1.646626|title=MBRSC launches the Project Space Forum on January 24|last=Staff|date=2017-01-18|work=Emirates 24{{!}}7|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.projectspace.ae/?acme_speaker=astronaut-abby-harrison|title=Project Space Event 2017 by Mohammed bin Rashid Space Centre|website=www.projectspace.ae|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>
====STEM in 30 show====
(2017) – The Mars Generation founder, [[Abigail Harrison]] represented The Mars Generation as a guest on the live broadcast of the [[science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]] in 30 show produced by [[National Air and Space Museum]] of the [[Smithsonian Institution]] and sponsored by [[NASA]]. The show is geared towards elementary and middle school classrooms.<ref>{{Citation|title=STEM in 30 (TV Series 2014– )|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6773292/|accessdate=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://airandspace.si.edu/events/women-paving-way-mars|title=The Women Paving the Way to Mars|date=2016-09-02|work=National Air and Space Museum|access-date=2017-08-14|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum|title=The Women Paving the Way to Mars – STEM in 30|date=2017-04-13|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hICKTEu2Ig0|accessdate=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum|title=The Women Paving the Way to Mars – STEM in 30|date=2017-04-13|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hICKTEu2Ig0|accessdate=2017-08-14}}</ref>
====Kennedy Space Center Visitors Center Complex====
(2017) – As part of the [[NASA]] [[Kennedy Space Center Visitors Center]] Summer Of Mars Initiative The Mars Generation founder [[Abigail Harrison]] appeared to speak and for a photo opportunity to represent the nonprofit.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kennedyspacecenter.com/events/events-calendar/2017/august/event-astronaut-abby-appearance|title=Aspiring Astronaut Abby Appearance and Photo Opportunity|website=www.kennedyspacecenter.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kennedyspacecenter.com/summerofmars?gclid=CjwKEAjw8b_MBRDcz5-03eP8ykISJACiRO5Zu8EFeiolr7QFVJscUIcWvu37iK5bgVRZ4TYh3pariBoC0z3w_wcB|title=Summer of Mars {{!}} Kennedy Space Center|website=www.kennedyspacecenter.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-14}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{infobox book | | name = The Sentimental Agents in the Volyen Empire | image = Lessing SentimentalAgents.jpg | caption = US first edition cover ([[Alfred A. Knopf]]) | author = [[Doris Lessing]] | cover_artist = Paul Gamarello | country = {{plainlist| *United States *United Kingdom }} | language = English | series = ''[[Canopus in Argos]]'' | genre = [[Novel]] ([[science fiction]]) | published = 1983 ([[Alfred A. Knopf]], US, [[Jonathan Cape]], UK | media_type = Print (hardcover) | pages = 178 | isbn = 0-394-52968-5 | isbn_note = (US)
0-224-02130-3 (UK) | dewey= 823/.914 19 | congress= PR6023.E833 D59 1983 | oclc= 9154744 | preceded_by = [[The Making of the Representative for Planet 8]] }} '''''(Documents Relating to) The Sentimental Agents in the Volyen Empire''''' is a 1983 science fiction novel by [[Doris Lessing]]. It is the fifth book in her five-book ''[[Canopus in Argos]]'' series{{cite web |url=http://www.dorislessing.org/canopusin.html |title=Canopus in Argos: Archives |work=dorislessing.org |accessdate=16 December 2008}} and comprises a set of documents that describe the final days of the Volyen Empire, located at the edge of our galaxy and under the influence of three other galactic empires, the benevolent [[Canopus]], the tyrannical [[Sirius]], and the malicious Shammat of Puttiora. It was first published in the United States in March 1983 by [[Alfred A. Knopf]], and in the United Kingdom in May 1983 by [[Jonathan Cape]]. ''The Sentimental Agents in the Volyen Empire'' is a social satire written in the tradition of [[Jonathan Swift]] and [[George Orwell]],{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=980DE4DF1539F937A25750C0A965948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all |title=Books of the Times: The Sentimental Agents in the Volyen Empire |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Michiko |last=Kakutani |authorlink=Michiko Kakutani |accessdate=16 December 2008 | date=14 March 1983}} and focuses on the debasement of language in [[rhetoric|political rhetoric]].{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D04EED61039F930A35757C0A965948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all |title=Against Galactic Rhetoric |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Edward |last=Rothstein |authorlink=Edward Rothstein |accessdate=16 December 2008 | date=3 April 1983}} In Lessing's [[fictional universe]] it is propaganda that keeps the fragile empires afloat, and when language becomes too distorted, some of her characters succumb to a condition called "undulant rhetoric" and are placed in a Hospital for Rhetorical Diseases.{{sfn|Lessing|1994c|loc=pp. 11 & 15}} Because of its focus on characterisation and social/cultural issues, and the de-emphasis of technological details, this book is not strictly science fiction but [[soft science fiction]], or "space fiction" as Lessing calls her ''Canopus in Argos'' series.{{sfn|Lessing|1994a|loc="Some Remarks", p. 8}} While ''The Sentimental Agents'' can be read as a stand-alone book, Lessing does continue with the history of the Sirian Empire, picking up from where she left off in ''[[The Sirian Experiments]]'' (1980), the third book in the ''Canopus'' series.{{sfn|Lessing|1994b}}{{sfn|Lessing|1994c}} ==Reception== [[Edward Rothstein]] in a review in ''[[The New York Times]]'' describes ''The Sentimental Agents in the Volyen Empire'' as "a satirical romp through rhetoric in a foreign empire", but complains that the tone of the book "wavers uncertainly, mixing farce, cynicism and banal religiosity." In another New York Times review, [[Michiko Kakutani]] writes that in this book Lessing has "narrowed her cosmic focus to a specific issue, namely the manipulative use of language and words" which, she believes, was handled with "more acerbity and more humour" by [[George Orwell]] in ''[[Animal Farm]]'' (1945) and ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four]]'' (1949). ==Plot== The Volyen Empire is a relatively weak interstellar empire situated at the edge of our galaxy.{{sfn|Lessing|1994c|loc=p. 13}} It comprises the planet Volyen, its two moons, Volyenadna and Volyendesta (also referred to as planets), and two neighbouring planets, Maken and Slovin.{{sfn|Lessing|1994c|loc=p. 12}} Intelligent life evolved independently on each of these five "planets", and over time unstable empires formed, where each planet for a period ruled the others. The Volyen Empire is the last of these empires and rules the region with force and repression. Although this system is at the edge of the Canopean Empire's sphere of influence, Canopus sends agents to the region because Volyen's colonisation of Maken and Slovin provoked the Sirian Empire who had earmarked these planets for "possible expansion". In addition, Shammat, Canopus's enemy, had established a presence in the region. Disillusioned and oppressed, the citizens of Volyen and its colonies start speaking out against the Volyen government. Revolutionary groups form and counter the Empire's rhetoric with rhetoric of their own. Krolgul of Shammat, buoyed by the turmoil, encourages anti-government behaviour. Klorathy, a senior Canopean Colonial administrator, is sent to Volyen to observe the unfolding events, and to monitor Incent, one of his agents who has been caught up in the sentiment of the revolutionary rhetoric. Incent has also fallen prey to Krolgul's propaganda and is withdrawn from the field by Klorathy and placed in a Hospital for Rhetorical Diseases on Volyendesta.{{sfn|Lessing|1994c|loc=p. 15}} Sirius is now threatening to invade the region, and this is welcomed by the downtrodden in the Volyen Empire because they are sure that Sirius will set them free. Many citizens became Sirian agents and provide Sirius with information and support. But the Sirian Empire is itself in turmoil. A conflict on Sirius split the governing oligarchy into the Questioners, led by the Five who want Sirius's expansion program halted, and the Conservers, who believe Sirius should continue colonising other planets.{{sfn|Lessing|1994c|loc=p.14}} The Five were defeated and Sirius resumed its expansion, but this time with an uncontrolled brutality that turned the Sirian Empire into a tyranny. When the Sirian agents learn about Sirius's tyranny, their loyalties are divided between Sirius and Volyen, and they become known as "sentimental agents".{{sfn|Lessing|1994c|loc=p.190}} Sirius invades the Volyen Empire with troops from nearby Sirian occupied planets. The troops, themselves colonial subjects of the now declining Sirian Empire, were told that Volyen is poor and deprived and needs Sirius's help. But when they land they discover that the Volyens are better off than they are, and return home and declare their own planets independent from Sirius. Volyenadna and Volyendesta, with Klorathy's help, become self-sustaining and declare ''their'' independence from the crumbling Volyen Empire. The change of circumstances in the region weakens Krolgul and his influence, and he returns to Shammat. Incent, now "recovered" from his illness, decides that he is going to help Krolgul. Klorathy, still Incent's custodian, follows him to Shammat. ==Characters== {{Quote box | quote = "It can be considered a rule that the probable duration of an Empire may be prognosticated by the degree to which its rulers believe in their own propaganda." | width = 32% | source = —Extract from a report used by Klorathy in the Canopean Colonial Service classes he taught.{{sfn|Lessing|1994c|loc=p.94}} | align = right | salign = center | bgcolor = #F0F0F0}} ;Volyen Empire *Grice – Volyen governor on Volyenadna *Calder – miners' leader on Volyenadna *Ormarin – rebel leader on Volyendesta ;Canopus *Klorathy – senior Canopean Colonial administrator *Incent – Canopean agent ;Shammat *Krolgul – Shammat representative to Volyen ==References== {{reflist|30em}} '''Virtual Design and Construction''' (VDC) is the management of integrated multi-disciplinary performance models of [[design]]-[[construction]] projects, including the product (i.e., [[Building|facilities]]), [[Workflow|work processes]] and [[organization]] of the design - construction - operation team in order to support explicit and [[Public works|public business]] objectives.<ref>[http://cife.stanford.edu/Mission/index.html "CIFE Mission Statement" CIFE website, retrieved December 2007;]</ref>
The theoretical basis of VDC includes:<ref>[http://cife.stanford.edu/Mission/index.html "CIFE Mission Statement" CIFE website, retrieved December 2007;]</ref>
* [[Engineering]] [[scientific modelling|modeling]] methods: [[Product (business)|product]], [[organization]], [[Business process|process]] * [[Analysis]] methods - [[Model-based design]]: including [[Quantity|quantities]], [[Schedule (project management)|schedule]], [[cost]], [[Spacetime|4D]] interactions and [[Risk management#Risk management activities as applied to project management|process risks]], these are termed [[Building Information Modeling|Building Information Modeling (BIM) tools]] * [[Product visualization|Visualization]] methods * Business metrics - within [[Business analytics]] - and a focus on [[strategic management]] * [[Economic impact analysis]], i.e., models of both the [[cost]] and [[Value (economics)|value]] of [[capital investments]]
== VDC Managed Project ==
"Virtual Design and Construction BIMs are [[Virtuality|virtual]] because they show [[Computer-based assessment|computer-based]] descriptions of the project. The BIM project model emphasizes those aspects of the project that can be designed and managed, i.e., the ''[[Product (business)|product]]'' (typically a [[building]] or [[Factory|plant]] [and infrastructure]), the ''[[organization]]'' that will define, [[design]], [[construction|construct]] and [[operate]] it, and the ''[[Business process|process]]'' that the organization teams will follow, or POP {{Definition needed|date=March 2018}}. These models are [[logically]] integrated in the sense that they all can access [[Concurrent data structure|shared data]], and if a user highlights or changes an aspect of one, the integrated models can highlight or change the dependent aspects of related models. The models are [[multi-disciplinary]] in the sense that they represent the [[Architect]], [[Engineering]], [[Construction]] (AEC) and [[Owner]] of the project, as well as relevant sub-disciplines. The models are [[Performance test (assessment)|performance models]] in the sense that they predict some aspects of project performance, track many that are relevant, and can show predicted and measured performance in relationship to stated project performance objectives. Some companies now practice the first steps of BIM modeling, and they consistently find that they improve business performance by doing so."<ref>John Kunz & Martin Fischer "Virtual Design and Construction: Themes, Case Studies and Implementation Suggestions" Stanford University CIFE Working Paper # 97, October 2009. [http://cife.stanford.edu/sites/default/files/WP097_0.pdf]</ref> Companies are also now considering developing BIMs in various levels of detail, since depending on the application of BIM, more or less detail is needed, and there is varying modeling effort associated with generating building information models at different levels of detail.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.autcon.2010.11.027 |title=Analysis of modeling effort and impact of different levels of detail in building information models |year=2011 |last1=Leite |first1=F |last2=Akcamete |first2=A |last3=Akinci |first3=B |last4=Atasoy |first4=G |last5=Kiziltas |first5=S |journal=Automation in Construction |volume=20 |issue=5 |pages=601–609}}</ref>
== Methodologies Underpinning VDC == Advancements in construction engineering began with the ten volumes on architecture completed by [[Vitruvius]], a 1 century B.C. Roman. Vitruvi laid the foundation for the study of construction.
A principle of construction is the use of an [[Applied ontology]] based in an [[Upper ontology (information science)|Upper ontology]]. In practice these ontologies take on the form of breakdown structures such as the [[Work breakdown structure]]. Usually these breakdown structures form [[Metadata]] to represent a construction activity. In practice, this requires a [[Semantic integration]] approach to construction data so to capture the project status.
The research that formed VDC is based in [[Scientific evidence]]. This was a departure from earlier construction engineering that focused on studies of best practices. This required formulating a [[Hypothesis]] and then testing to validate. A range of methodologies have proven useful in construction engineering research, both [[Qualitative research]] and [[Quantitative research]]. Because construction is difficult to replicate in a controlled setting, the [[Case-based reasoning]] || [[Case study]] and [[Action research]] methodologies prevail. These methodologies have different [[Power of a method]], where the case study is often broad and the action research focused.
A core concept of VDC is the [[Spacetime]]. There are four dimensions, these three space dimensions and then a fourth: time. There are additional dimensions of cost and quality, but the core are these four. These four dimensions in design were first understood by Vitruvi as the importance of perspective and time. Prior to the use of computing, the focus was on the fourth dimension time. In practice, this is the [[Critical path method]]. With advances in computing, the representation of the three dimensions of space has increased. The merging of space and the above discussed ontology formed the [[Information model]], in the construction engineering field, known as [[Building Information Modeling]]. The combination of space and time in practice is shown by the [[Linear scheduling method]] and in close relation the 4D model.
Computing brought about the advent of the need to align with a software developer. Previously, pencil and paper was forgiving on the mixing of methods from different schools of thought. Software is not as forgiving and to mix software requires this as a goal. This forms the field of [[Interoperability]] research. The practical application is demonstrated by the [[Industry Foundation Classes]].
Today, the most compelling advances in VDC are in computer vision ([[List of computer vision topics]]) and the architecture of transmission (AoT), an object-oriented project lifecycle management process, which acts as a counterpoint to commissioned IoT technologies. [http://cife.stanford.edu/]
An important application of VDC is in the workzone. This is where the construction activities reside, and the workforce is a core component. To create an educated workforce with the technical knowhow to use the technology tools now available, VDC includes the development of advanced [[Vocational education]] topics.

{{Infobox Institute | name = Wellcome Sanger Institute | image = [[File:Sanger Logo.png]] | established = 1992 | head_label = Director | head = [[Michael Stratton]] | president = | faculty = 37 | staff = ~900{{citation needed|date=November 2015}} | budget = | endowment = | debt = | city = [[Hinxton]] | state = [[Cambridgeshire]], [[United Kingdom]] | address = [[Wellcome Genome Campus]] | website = {{URL|sanger.ac.uk}} }}
The '''Wellcome Sanger Institute''', previously known as '''The Sanger Centre''' and '''Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute''', is a [[non-profit organisation|non-profit]] British [[genomics]] and [[genetics]] research institute, primarily funded by the [[Wellcome Trust]].<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.cggh.ox.ac.uk/?title=MRC_Centre_United_Kingdom#Wellcome_Trust_Sanger_Institute | title = MRC Centre United Kingdom: Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute | publisher = [[Medical Research Council (UK)|Medical Research Council]] | accessdate = 2008-12-22 }}</ref>
It is located on the [[Wellcome Genome Campus]] by the village of [[Hinxton]], outside [[Cambridge]]. It shares this location with the [[European Bioinformatics Institute]]. It was established in 1992 and named after double [[Nobel Laureate]], [[Frederick Sanger]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Walker | first1 = John | authorlink = John E. Walker | title = [[Frederick Sanger]] (1918–2013) Double Nobel-prizewinning genomics pioneer | doi = 10.1038/505027a | journal = Nature | volume = 505 | issue = 7481 | pages = 27 | year = 2014 | pmid = 24380948 | pmc = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Sanger | first1 = F. | doi = 10.1146/annurev.bi.57.070188.000245 | title = Sequences, Sequences, and Sequences | journal = Annual Review of Biochemistry | volume = 57 | pages = 1–29 | year = 1988 | pmid = 2460023| pmc = }}</ref> It was conceived as a large scale [[DNA sequencing]] centre to participate in the [[Human Genome Project]], and went on to make the largest single contribution to the gold standard sequence of the [[human genome]]. From its inception the Institute established and has maintained a policy of [[data sharing]], and does much of its research in [[collaboration]].
Since 2000, the Institute expanded its mission to understand "the role of genetics in health and disease".<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.sanger.ac.uk/about/ | title = Wellcome Sanger Institute - About us | publisher = Wellcome Sanger Institute | accessdate = 2010-06-28 }}</ref> The Institute now employs around 900 people{{citation needed|date=November 2015}} and engages in four main areas of research: Human genetics, pathogen genetics, [[Laboratory mouse|mouse]] and [[Zebrafish#In scientific research|zebrafish]] genetics and [[bioinformatics]].
==Facilities and resources==
===Campus=== [[File:Sanger Institute and Hinxton Hall, Cambridge, UK.jpg|300px|thumb|The Wellcome Genome Campus]] [[File:DNA Helix and Tree of Life stain glass window.JPG|thumbnail|right|Commemorative stain window located in the Sulston building of the Wellcome Sanger Institute, to mark the opening of the Genome Campus.]] In 1993 the then 17 Sanger Centre staff moved into temporary laboratory space at Hinxton Hall<ref name="sanger1"/> in [[Cambridgeshire]]. This {{convert|55|acre|m2|adj=on}} site was to become the Wellcome Genome Campus, which has a growing population of around 1300 staff, approximately 900 of whom work at the Sanger Institute.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/careers/|title=Wellcome Sanger Institute - Work and study|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|accessdate=2010-06-28}}</ref> The Genome Campus also includes the Wellcome Trust Conference Centre<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtconference.org/|title=Welcome to the Wellcome Genome Campus Conference Centre|author=|date=|website=Wellcome Genome Campus Conference Centre|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref> and the [[European Bioinformatics Institute]]. A major extension of the campus was officially opened in 2005;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/Info/Press/2005/051014.shtml|title=Wellcome Trust Genome Campus Extension Opened: Visit by Her Royal Highness, The Princess Royal|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|accessdate=2009-01-07}}</ref> the buildings accommodate new laboratories, a [[data centre]] and staff amenities.<ref name=datacentre>{{Cite journal | last1 = Doctorow | first1 = C. | authorlink1 = Cory Doctorow| title = Big data: Welcome to the petacentre | doi = 10.1038/455016a | journal = Nature | volume = 455 | issue = 7209 | pages = 16–21 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18769411| pmc = }}</ref> In discussing the name of the centre, Sanger (still alive when the centre was opened) told [[John Sulston]], the founding director, that the centre "had better be good." Sulston commented, "I rather wished I hadn’t asked."<ref name="Interview with John Sulston">{{cite web|last1=Sulston|first1=John|title=Interview with John Sulston|url=http://library.cshl.edu/oralhistory/interview/scientific-experience/molecular-biologists/sulston-frederick-sanger/|publisher=Cold Spring Harbor Laboratories digital archive|accessdate=13 November 2015}}</ref>
===Sequencing=== The Sanger Institute's sequencing staff handle millions of [[DNA]] samples each week.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}} The Institute "capitalises on leading-edge technologies to answer questions unanswerable only a few years ago".<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.sanger.ac.uk/resources/technologies/sequencing.html|title=Wellcome Sanger Institute - Sequencing|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|accessdate=2010-06-28}}</ref> The advances in technology allow the Sanger Institute to carry out sequencing of the genomes of individual humans, [[vertebrate]] [[species]] and [[pathogens]], at an ever-increasing pace and reducing cost. The Institute has more than 100 ongoing pathogen sequencing projects.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.sanger.ac.uk/research/projects/pathogengenomics/|title=Wellcome Sanger Institute - Pathogen genomics|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|accessdate=2010-06-28}}</ref> The output of the Sanger Institute is around 10 billion [[base pair|bases]] of raw sequence data per day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/News/2008/Features/WTX052290.htm|author=Jones, I|title=Feature: Highly cited|publisher=Wellcome Trust|accessdate=2009-01-22}}</ref>

==Research== {{update|section|date=April 2015}} [[File:Hinxton hall.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Morgan Building (right), part of the Sanger Institute]] Since 2000, the Sanger Institute has built on its [[sequencing]] skills to develop new programmes in postgenomic [[biology]] - understanding the messages in [[genes]]. As of 2016 (when the Institute's latest 5-year funding plan began), the Institute engages in several areas of research:
=== [[Cancer, Ageing and Somatic Mutation Programme]] === Provides leadership in data aggregation and informatics innovation, develops high-throughput cellular models of cancer for genome-wide functional screens and drug testing, and explores somatic mutation's role in clonal evolution, ageing and development.
=== [[Cellular Genetics Programme]] === Explores human gene function by studying the impact of genome variation on cell biology. Large-scale systematic screens are used to discover the impact of naturally occurring and engineered genome mutations in human induced pluripotent cells (hIPSCs), their differentiated derivatives and other cell types. It is one of the founder programmes driving the creation and organisation of the international [[Human Cell Atlas]] initiative.
===[[Human Genetics Programme]]=== The Institute's research in [[human genetics]] focuses on the characterisation of [[human genetic variation]] in health and disease. Aside from the Institute's contribution to the [[Human Genome Project]], researchers at the Sanger Institute have made contributions in various research areas relating to disease, population comparative and [[Extended evolutionary synthesis|evolutionary genetics]]. In January 2008, the launch of the [[1000 Genomes Project]], a collaboration with scientists around the globe, signalled an effort to sequence the genomes of 1000 individuals in order to create the "most detailed map of human genetic variation to support disease studies".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.1000genomes.org/page.php|title=1000 Genomes: A Deep Catalog of Human Genetic Variation|publisher=1000 Genomes Project|accessdate=2008-12-22}}</ref> The data from the pilot projects was made freely available in public databases in June 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/about/press/2010/100621.html|title=1000 Genomes Project releases data from pilot projects on path to providing database for 2,500 human genomes|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|accessdate=2010-06-28}}</ref> In 2010, the Sanger Institute announced its participation in the UK10K project,<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 24424120 | pmc = 4026295 | year = 2014 | author1 = Kaye | first1 = J | title = Managing clinically significant findings in research: The UK10K example | journal = European Journal of Human Genetics | volume = 22 | issue = 9 | pages = 1100–4 | last2 = Hurles | first2 = M | last3 = Griffin | first3 = H | last4 = Grewal | first4 = J | last5 = Bobrow | first5 = M | authorlink5 = Martin Bobrow | last6 = Timpson | first6 = N | last7 = Smee | first7 = C | last8 = Bolton | first8 = P | last9 = Durbin | first9 = R | authorlink9 = Richard M. Durbin | last10 = Dyke | first10 = S | last11 = Fitzpatrick | first11 = D | last12 = Kennedy | first12 = K | last13 = Kent | first13 = A | last14 = Muddyman | first14 = D | last15 = Muntoni | first15 = F | last16 = Raymond | first16 = L. F. | last17 = Semple | first17 = R | last18 = Spector | first18 = T | last19 = Uk | first19 = 10K | doi = 10.1038/ejhg.2013.290 }} {{open access}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 24229443 | pmc = 3978569 | year = 2013 | author1 = Muddyman | first1 = D | title = Implementing a successful data-management framework: The UK10K managed access model | journal = Genome Medicine | volume = 5 | issue = 11 | pages = 100 | last2 = Smee | first2 = C | last3 = Griffin | first3 = H | last4 = Kaye | first4 = J | doi = 10.1186/gm504 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/about/press/2010/100624-uk10k.html|title=Wellcome Trust launches study of 10,000 human genomes in UK|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|accessdate=2010-06-28}}</ref> which will sequence the genomes of 10,000 individuals to identify rare genetic variants and their effects on human health. The Sanger Institute is also part of the [[International Cancer Genome Consortium]], an international effort to describe different cancer [[tumour]] types.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icgc.org/|title=International Cancer Genome Consortium Homepage|publisher=International Cancer Genome Consortium|accessdate=2009-01-23}}</ref> It is also part of the [[GENCODE]] and [[ENCODE]] research programmes<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/resources/databases/encode//|title=Wellcome Sanger Institute - ENCODE and GENCODE|accessdate=2010-06-28}}</ref> to create an encyclopaedia of DNA elements.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
The Programme applies genomics to population-scale studies to identify the causal variants and pathways involved in human disease and their effects on cell biology. It also models developmental disorders to explore which physical aspects might be reversible.
===Infection Genomics Programme=== Investigates the common underpinning mechanisms of evolution, infection and resistance to therapy into bolster understanding of [[bacteria]], [[virus]]es and [[parasitism|parasites.]] It also explores the effects of genome variation on the biology of [[host (biology)|host]]-[[pathogen]] interactions, in particular host response to infection and the role of microiotia in health and disease. All the genomes after sequencing are made available at the web-based onsite-maintained database, GeneDB.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
=== Malaria Programme === Integrates genomic, genetic and proteomic approaches to develop and enhance high-throughput tools and technologies to study specific biological problems relevant for malaria control and to understand the fundamental science of the human host, the mosquito vector and the ''Plasmodium'' pathogen.
=== Facilities/Expertise === All of this research is underpinned by expertise in a number of key areas:
===Bioinformatics=== The Sanger Institute's bioinformatics teams have developed [[Information Technology|IT]] systems for sequencing and postgenomic research. The Institute houses genome resources, RNA, protein and other [[family (biology)|family]] resources and functional annotation databases and resources. Researchers worldwide are able to use these resources to make [[inferences]] of genomic knowledge through computational analysis and integration of data.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
===Model organisms=== [[Laboratory mouse|Mouse]] and [[Zebrafish#In scientific research|zebrafish]] teams at the Sanger Institute enable Sanger researchers to explore the genome sequences of these [[model organisms]] to understand basic biological mechanisms, and gene function in human health and disease. Project supported include the study of development, cancer, hearing and behaviour.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
=== Experimental biological models === {{ad|date=August 2018}} With the creation of the Sanger Institute-EBI Single Cell Centre and the Cellular Generation and Phenotyping]pipeline, the Institute has developed state-of-the-art human induced pluripotent stem cell, induced pluripotent stem cell, single cell and [[organoid]] facilties to deliver the next generation of biological models.

===Public engagement=== [[File:Sanger Institute outreach DNA bracelets.jpg|thumb|Children at a public outreach event thread bracelets in four colours to spell out a DNA sequence.]] The Sanger Institute has a programme of [[public engagement]] activity. The programme aims to make complex biomedical research accessible to a range of audiences including school students and their teachers, and local community members.
The Communication and Public Engagement programme aims to "encourage informed discussion about issues relevant to Sanger Institute research"<ref name="Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute" /> and "foster a community of researchers who can engage effectively with different audiences".<ref name="Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute">{{cite web|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/Teams/Team104/|title=Team 104: Communication and Public Engagement Programme|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|accessdate=2009-01-12}}</ref> The Institute hosts visits for more than 1,500 students, teachers and community groups per year. Visitors may meet scientific staff, tour the Institute and its facilities, and participate in ethical debates and activities. The programme also offers professional development sessions for teachers of [[GCSE]] and post 16 science through the national network of [[Science Learning Centres]], and by hosting visits for groups interested in updating their knowledge in contemporary genetics. [[Videoconferencing]] into the Sanger Institute is also offered for Science Learning Centres, Science Centres and schools.
The programme maintains a dedicated public website, yourgenome.org,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yourgenome.org/|title=yourgenome.org|author=|date=|website=www.yourgenome.org|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref> that is intended to help people understand [[genetics]] and [[genomics]] science and its implications for society. The website includes teaching resources for [[secondary school]] science teachers that have been developed with Institute researchers.
Scientific and public engagement staff also collaborate on and contribute to national projects such as the UK's ''InsideDNA''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insidedna.org.uk/content/|title=InsideDNA|author=|date=|website=insidedna.org.uk|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref> traveling exhibition and the ''Who am I?'' gallery at [[Science Museum (London)|The Science Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sciencemuseum.org.uk/|title=Home - Science Museum|author=|date=|website=Science Museum|accessdate=30 March 2018}}</ref> They also participate in public events such as the Cambridge Science Festival.
===Graduate training=== The Institute operates two PhD training programmes: a four-year course for basic science graduates, and a three-year course for clinicians. The four-year course requires students to rotate around three different laboratories in order to broaden their scientific horizons before choosing a PhD project. Each student is required to choose at least one experimental and one informatics-based rotation project.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.sanger.ac.uk/careers/phd/ | title = Wellcome Sanger Institute PhD Programmes | publisher = Wellcome Sanger Institute | accessdate = 2009-11-13 }}</ref> Institute houses approximately 50 pre-doctoral students, all of whom are registered at the [[University of Cambridge]].<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407104250/http://www.sanger.ac.uk/research/publications/theses.html|title=Sanger PhD and MPhil theses|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/research/publications/theses.html|archivedate=2015-04-07}}</ref>
==Staff==
{{As of|2015}} the Sanger employs around 900 people, and is led by [[Michael Stratton]]. Notable scientific staff, [[Faculty (academic staff)|faculty]] and alumni are listed below:
===Academic faculty=== {{As of|2015}} a faculty of 42 scientists lead [[hypothesis]]-driven research, seeking answers to biomedical questions.<ref name=faculty>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316171820/http://www.sanger.ac.uk/research/faculty/|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/research/faculty/|title=Sanger Faculty|archivedate=2015-03-16}}</ref> These include:
{{Div col|colwidth=35em}} * [[Allan Bradley]] [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]]- Mouse genomics * Peter Campbell - [[Cancer Genome Project]] * [[Gordon Dougan]]<ref name=douganswho>{{Who's Who | surname = Dougan | othernames = Prof. Gordon| id = U281223 |doi=10.1093/ww/9780199540884.013.U281223| author=Anon|year = 2015 | edition = online [[Oxford University Press]]}} {{subscription required}}</ref> FRS - Microbial [[pathogenesis]] * [[Richard M. Durbin|Richard Durbin]]<ref name=durbinswho>{{Who's Who | surname = Durbin | othernames = Richard Michael | id = U45024 | year = 2015|author=Anon | doi=10.1093/ww/9780199540884.013.U45024|edition = online edition via [[Oxford University Press]]}} {{subscription required}}</ref> FRS - Genome informatics * [[Dominic Kwiatkowski]] FRS parasites and microbes programme * Ultan McDermott - [[Cancer Genome Project]] * [[Julian Parkhill]] FRS - Pathogen genomics * [[Julian Rayner]] - Malaria * [[Nicole Soranzo]] - diseases<ref>https://www.sanger.ac.uk/people/directory/soranzo-nicole</ref> * [[Michael Stratton]] - [[Cancer Genome Project]] * [[Sarah Teichmann]]<ref name=teichmann>{{Scopus|id=7003495551|title=Sarah Teichmann}}</ref> - Gene expression genomics * [[Eleftheria Zeggini]]<ref name=elezeg>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151111122324/http://www.sanger.ac.uk/people/directory/zeggini-eleftheria|archivedate=2015-11-11|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/people/directory/zeggini-eleftheria|title=Professor Eleftheria Zeggini, Group Leader|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|location=Hinxton}}</ref> human genetics {{colend}}
===Associate faculty and international fellows=== Associate Faculty members work [[Part-time contract|part-time]] at the Sanger usually jointly with another organisation.<ref name=faculty/> {{As of|2015}} there are 16 associate faculty including:
{{Div col|colwidth=35em}} * [[Adrian Bird]] FRS - Epigenetic mechanisms in health and disease, Professor at the [[University of Edinburgh]] * [[Ewan Birney]] FRS,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Pennisi | first1 = Elizabeth | title = Profile of Ewan Birney: Genomics' Big Talker | doi = 10.1126/science.337.6099.1167 | journal = [[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume = 337 | issue = 6099 | pages = 1167–1169 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22955814 | pmc = }}</ref> based at the [[European Bioinformatics Institute]] * John Danesh, Professor in the Department of [[Public Health]] and [[Primary Care]] at the University of Cambridge * [[Chris Ponting]] - Computational genome biology, based at the [[University of Oxford]] * [[Fiona Powrie]], FRS, University of Oxford<ref name=powrieswho>{{Who's Who | surname = POWRIE | othernames = Prof. Fiona Margaret | id = U255684 | volume = 2015 | edition = online [[Oxford University Press]]}} {{subscription required}}</ref> * [[Stephen O'Rahilly]], Professor at the [[University of Cambridge]] * [[Wolf Reik]] - [[Epigenetic]] reprogramming, based at the [[Babraham Institute]] * Toni Vidal-Puig, Professor of Molecular Nutrition and Metabolism at the Institute of Metabolic Science, University of Cambridge {{colend}}
===Scientific Advisory Board===
The Sanger [[Board of directors|Board of Management]] are guided by the scientific [[advisory board]]<ref name=sab>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407104047/http://www.sanger.ac.uk/about/people/advisory.html|title=Sanger Advisory Board|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/about/people/advisory.html|archivedate=2015-04-07}}</ref> whose members include Professor [[David Altshuler]], Professor [[Anton Berns]], Professor [[David J. Lipman]], Professor Kevin Marsh and Professor Sir [[Paul Nurse]].
===Honorary faculty=== The Sanger has an Honorary Faculty of researchers based at other research centres<ref name=honorary>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407055312/http://www.sanger.ac.uk/research/faculty/honoraryfaculty/|title=Honorary Faculty|publisher=Welcome Sanger Institute|archivedate=2015-04-07|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/research/faculty/honoraryfaculty/}}</ref> This includes:
{{Div col|colwidth=35em}} * [[Martin Bobrow]] * Gad Frankel - Cell and molecular biology of bacterial infection, Professor at [[Imperial College London]] * Andy Futreal - [[Cancer Genome Project]], based at the [[University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center]] * [[John Sulston]], [[University of Manchester]] - [[Research ethics|Science ethics]], former Director {{colend}}
===Alumni=== {{As of|2015}} previous faculty members at the Sanger include:<ref name=alumni>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407104218/http://www.sanger.ac.uk/research/faculty/previousfaculty/|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/research/faculty/previousfaculty/|title=Previous faculty at the Sanger|archivedate=2015-04-07}}</ref> {{Div col|colwidth=35em}} *[[Alex Bateman]], [[European Molecular Biology Laboratory|EMBL]]-[[European Bioinformatics Institute|EBI]]<ref name=wiki>{{Cite journal | last1 = Logan | first1 = D. W. | last2 = Sandal | first2 = M. | last3 = Gardner | first3 = P. P. | authorlink3 = | last4 = Manske | first4 = M. | authorlink4 = Magnus Manske | last5 = Bateman | first5 = A. | authorlink5 = Alex Bateman | title = Ten Simple Rules for Editing Wikipedia | doi = 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1000941 | journal = [[PLOS Computational Biology]] | volume = 6 | issue = 9 | pages = e1000941 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20941386 | pmc =2947980 }} {{open access}}</ref> *[[Tim Hubbard]], Professor at [[King's College London]] *[[Leena Peltonen-Palotie]] (1952 – 2010)<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = van Ommen | first1 = Gertjan | title = Obituary: [[Leena Peltonen-Palotie]] (1952–2010) A visionary in medical genetics. | doi = 10.1038/464992a | journal = [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] | volume = 464 | issue = 7291 | pages = 992–992 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20393553 | pmc = }}</ref> {{colend}}
==History== [[File:EBI and Sanger Center, Genome campus, Cambridgeshire.jpg|350px|right|thumb|The Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute was established in 1992, funded by the [[Wellcome Trust]] and the UK's [[Medical Research Council (UK)|Medical Research Council]]. One of the primary goals of the Institute on its creation, was to "play a role in mapping, sequencing and decoding the [[human genome]] and the genomes of other organisms".<ref name="sanger1">{{cite web|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/about/history/history.html|title=Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute - History|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|accessdate=2010-06-28}}</ref> The Sanger Institute now hosts several research programmes aiming to elucidate the associations between [[genes]] and [[trait (biology)|biological traits]] - most often disease susceptibilities. The Sanger Institute has, since inception, maintained a policy that "aims to provide rapid access to data sets of use to the research community".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/legal/|title=Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute - Data conditions|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|accessdate=2010-06-28}}</ref>]]
===Management === [[John E. Sulston]] was the founding Director of the Sanger Institute. Sulston was instrumental in the choice of the Hinxton site for the Institute and remained there as Director until the announcement of the completion of the draft human genome in 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.genome.gov/10001457|title=International Human Genome Sequencing Consortium Announces "Working Draft" of Human Genome|publisher=National Human Genome Research Institute|accessdate=2008-12-09}}</ref> Sulston graduated from the [[University of Cambridge]] in 1963 and completed his PhD on the chemical synthesis of DNA in 1966.<ref>{{cite book|author=Sulston J, Ferry G|title=The Common Thread: A story of Science, Politics, Ethics, and the Human Genome|year=2002|publisher=The Joseph Henry Press|page=18}}</ref> He shared the 2002 [[Nobel Prize]] in Physiology or Medicine with [[Robert Horvitz]] and [[Sydney Brenner]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/medicine/laureates/2002/|title=The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 2002|publisher=Nobel Prize|accessdate=2009-01-07}}</ref> two years after standing down as Director of the Institute.
In 2000, [[Allan Bradley]] left his appointment as Professor at the [[Baylor College of Medicine]], in the USA, to take up the position as Director of the Sanger Institute. Bradley wanted to build on the achievements made by the Sanger Institute in the Human Genome Project by "concentrating on gene function, cancer genomics, and the genomes of model organisms such as the mouse and the zebrafish".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://genomebiology.com/researchnews/default.asp?arx_id=gb-spotlight-20011106-02 |title=Sanger Institute looks to the future |publisher=Genome Biology |accessdate=2008-12-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040119195438/http://genomebiology.com/researchnews/default.asp?arx_id=gb-spotlight-20011106-02 |archivedate=January 19, 2004 }}</ref> Bradley received his BA, MA and PhD in Genetics from the University of Cambridge.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/Teams/faculty/bradley/|title=Professor Allan Bradley|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|archivedate=2015-04-07|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407061817/http://www.sanger.ac.uk/research/faculty/abradley/}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 10839511 | year = 2000 | author1 = Gura | first1 = T | title = Changing of the guard: Allan Bradley is to head the Sanger Centre, a powerhouse of the Human Genome Project | journal = Nature | volume = 405 | issue = 6785 | pages = 389 | doi = 10.1038/35013238 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 11606985 | year = 2001 | author1 = Adam | first1 = D | title = Sanger Centre welcomes gene funds with a new name | journal = Nature | volume = 413 | issue = 6857 | pages = 660 | doi = 10.1038/35099707 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 10830929 | year = 2000 | author1 = Dickson | first1 = D | title = Geneticist from Baylor named as new head of UK's Sanger Centre | journal = Nature | volume = 405 | issue = 6784 | pages = 264 | doi = 10.1038/35012766 }}</ref>
In 2010, Bradley stepped down from his leadership role to form a [[startup company]], but remains on the faculty of the Institute as Director Emeritus. [[Michael Stratton|Mike Stratton]], who is a leader of the [[Cancer Genome Project]] and the [[International Cancer Genome Consortium]], was appointed Director of the Sanger Institute in May of that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sanger.ac.uk/about/press/2010/100517.html |title=Professor Mike Stratton appointed new Director|publisher=Wellcome Sanger Institute|accessdate=2010-05-17}}</ref>
In August 2018 it was reported that an investigation was under way into allegations of bullying of staff and gender discrimination made against senior management of the [[Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute]], including the director.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/aug/29/wellcome-sanger-institute-bosses-accused-bullying-staff|title=Bosses at leading UK science institute accused of bullying staff|last=Marsh|first=Sarah|last2=Devlin|first2=Hannah|date=2018-08-29|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-08-29}}</ref> The independent investigation, carried out by the barrister Thomas Kibling from [[Matrix Chambers]], concluded in October 2018 and cleared Stratton of any wrongdoing, while listing areas for improvement in the workings of the Sanger Institute.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sanger.ac.uk/news/view/result-independent-investigation-whistleblowing-allegations-released |title=Result of independent investigation into whistleblowing allegations released |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2018-10-31|website=Sanger Institute|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sanger.ac.uk/sites/default/files/Oct2018/Thomas_Kibling_Investigatory_Report_-_Introduction_and_Executive_Summary.pdf |title=Thomas Kibling's Investigatory Report |author=Thomas Kibling |date=2018-10-31|website=Sanger Institute|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref>
=== Organizational and company spin outs{{Anchor|Congenica}} === The company Congenica was spun out of the Institute in the early 2000s to commercialize a clinical genetics analysis and reporting technology developed at the Institute, technology instantiated in Congenica's Sapientia platform.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.clinicalomics.com/articles/congenica-names-david-atkins-as-ceo/1459|title=Congenica Names David Atkins as CEO|last=<!-- no byline -->|first=|date=25 January 2018|work=ClinicalOMICs|access-date=26 January 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> Sapienta is used in several large scale genome intrepretation projects, including [[100,000 Genomes Project]] and [[FutureNeuro]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.genomeweb.com/neurological-psychological-disorders/congenica-teams-irelands-futureneuro-pursuit-better-epilepsy|title=Congenica Teams With Ireland's FutureNeuro in Pursuit of Better Epilepsy Diagnosis|last=<!--no byline-->|first=|date=12 February 2018|work=GenomeWeb|access-date=19 September 2018|location=New York City}}</ref> Congenica is based at the [[Wellcome Genome Campus|Welcome Genome Campus]], and completed a round of [[Series B financing]] in 2017.<ref name=":0" />
===Human Genome Project=== The Sanger Institute was opened in 1993, three years after the inception of the [[Human Genome Project]], and went on to make the largest single contribution to the gold standard sequence of the [[human genome]], published in 2004.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Human Genome Sequencing Consortium|title=Finishing the euchromatic sequence of the human genome|journal=Nature|year=2004|volume=431|pages=931–945|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v431/n7011/index.html|doi=10.1038/nature03001|pmid=15496913|issue=7011}}</ref> The Institute was engaged in collaborations to sequence 8 of the 23 human pairs of [[chromosomes]] ([[chromosome 1|1]], [[chromosome 6|6]], [[chromosome 9|9]], [[chromosome 10|10]], [[chromosome 13|13]], [[chromosome 20|20]], [[chromosome 22|22]], and [[X chromosome|X]]).<ref>{{cite journal|author=Pennisi E|title=Reaching Their Goal Early, Sequencing Labs Celebrate|journal=Science|year=2003|volume=300|page=409|url=http://www.scienceonline.org/cgi/content/full/300/5618/409|doi=10.1126/science.300.5618.409|pmid=12702850|issue=5618}}</ref> Since the publishing of the human genome, research carried out at the Institute has developed beyond sequencing of organisms into various biomedical research areas, including studies into diseases such as cancer, malaria and diabetes.
